body: Here is the 3d Chart. The data is all correct from Jan-Dec. Does not explain the lack of symmetry of the sky that was generated.  [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/fZ7LFFJLJtPX8krg-1O3ED3hzzvDYELSYP8285SIkj4h7OV2gri09eSOUzLfi2VCosDI1WWj3d5LndXA6osH15AXDGQp2*zP/hourlyData.PNG) [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/fZ7LFFJLJtPX8krg-1O3ED3hzzvDYELSYP8285SIkj4h7OV2gri09eSOUzLfi2VCosDI1WWj3d5LndXA6osH15AXDGQp2*zP/hourlyData.PNG) [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/fZ7LFFJLJtPX8krg-1O3ED3hzzvDYELSYP8285SIkj4h7OV2gri09eSOUzLfi2VCosDI1WWj3d5LndXA6osH15AXDGQp2*zP/hourlyData.PNG) Is there any other data besides location, direct normal radiation and diffuse horizontal radiation that is taken into account to produce the sky? My only explanation for this asymmetry is that some other data is being calculated or considered from other data sets that exist in the original epw file.
